section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Literacy: Read-Aloud Comprehension; Alphabet Knowledge; Phonological Awareness

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to talk about the alphabet (letters H h and Qq), engage children with song and introduce vocabulary (scent).
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking, How do the neighbors help Nita?
Read for enjoyment and understanding.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information to describe.
Produce at least 20 letter-sound correspondences; Write uppercase and lowercase letters.
Identify rhyming words.
Demonstrate empathy for others.
Make plans and take steps to a goal.
Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions; Know that people can speak different languages.
Recognize good habits of nutrition and exercise.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children focus on /h/ and /kw/.
Ask children to name words that begin like hat and quilt.
Invite children to draw a Happy Hippo or a Queen’s Quilt.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What stories do we like to tell?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Choose a book about food. What fruits do you see?
How would you make a fruit salad?
Choose some play foods to make a healthy snack.
Write or draw to show how to make a fruit salad.
Paint a picture of a fruit salad. What colors will you use?
Find the letters Qq and Hh in the Alphabet Books.
How can you use play clay to make different kinds of fruit?

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the make a plan Mind Builder to introduce the related vocabulary (help, together).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to Little Nita’s Big Idea.
Read closely and notice how Nita is making and carrying out her plan.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information to describe.
Demonstrate empathy for others.
Make plans and take steps to a goal.
Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.

section-block.tg_skills-focus_body: Fine Motor: Show emerging proficiency on tasks requiring eye-hand coordination (draw pictures recognizable to child but not others; cut with scissors but may not be able to cut across page.)

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children identify a goal and make a plan.
Guide children to follow the steps needed to reach the goal of making a paper pizza.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What stories do we like to tell?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What plan does the character in your book make?
Pretend you have a big mess to clean up. Show me how you could make the table clean!
How can you work together to finish a puzzle?
Draw or write something you plan to do later.
Draw a picture of something you plan to do later.
Find the letters in Nita’s name. Are any of those letters in your own name?
Make a plan for building a tower. What is the first step? What do you do next?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Little Nita’s Big Idea by Anna W. Bardaus, illustrated by Carolina Farias. Copyright © 2017 by Scholastic Inc. Published by Scholastic Inc. Clifford the Big Red DogTM illustration copyright © The Norman Bridwell Trust.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build background, clap syllables, and introduce new vocabulary words (peeled, ripe).
Begin Story Time by revisiting Little Nita’s Big Idea and asking the guiding question, What is special about Nita’s fruit salad?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information to describe.
Separate syllables from a word.
Contribute ideas and participate in group writing.
Demonstrate empathy for others.
Make plans and take steps to a goal.
Use regular and irregular plurals.
Recognize good habits of nutrition and exercise.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Ask children to identify pictures of different fruits.
Guide children to sort the fruits into fruits that name one (singular nouns) and fruits that name two (plural nouns).
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What stories do we like to tell?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: How is the character in your book like Little Nita?
What healthy snacks do you like to eat? Why?
How do you know if a food is healthy for you to eat?
Draw or write to show a healthy lunch.
Draw the steps to show how to make a fruit salad.
What letters do you know in the word apple? What letters do you know in the word banana?
Make a table and then sit down to eat a healthy snack.

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Little Nita’s Big Idea by Anna W. Bardaus, illustrated by Carolina Farias. Copyright © 2017 by Scholastic Inc. Published by Scholastic Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Photo © Food Travel Stockforlife/Shutterstock.

tg_materials-caption.tg_materials-caption_book-title-Ital: Big Chart of Big Ideas: The Voice in Rabbit’s House

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to talk about telling stories and introduce vocabulary word (rhinoceros).
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts, The Voice in Rabbit’s House and Little Nita’s Big Idea.
Read closely to answer the weekly concept question: What stories do we like to tell?
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information to describe.
Write for different purposes; Independently write letters to make words or word parts.
Demonstrate empathy for others.
Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions; Understands a growing number of relational words.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Engage children in storytelling.
Ask children to take the storytelling pointer, point to a picture on the Big Chart and tell what is happening.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What stories do we like to tell?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Compare the characters in the book. Which did you like the most? Why?
Can you dress up like one of the animals from the story we read today?
Can you put the animals in the story from smallest to largest?
Draw a picture of when you used a big loud voice. What label could you put on your picture?
Can you make a house for Caterpillar?
Can you find the letter Hh in an Alphabet Book?
Can you build an animal that is big and an animal that is little?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Little Nita’s Big Idea by Anna W. Bardaus, illustrated by Carolina Farias. Copyright © 2017 by Scholastic Inc. Published by Scholastic Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Photo © nuwatphoto/Shutterstock.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to have children act out parts of the story and introduce the vocabulary words (marvelous, delicious).
Begin Story Time by revisiting Little Nita’s Big Idea and asking children to consider: If you were Nita’s neighbor, what would you do?
Read and retell interactively.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Share and repeat the details in a text.
Separate syllables from a word.
Write for different purposes; Independently write letters to make words or word parts.
Make plans and take steps to a goal.
Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: If you were Nita’s neighbor, how would you help?
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What stories do we like to tell?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Imagine that you are a character in the story you are reading. Which character would you be?
Pretend you are one of Nita’s neighbors. Let’s help make a delicious fruit salad!
Pretend the pattern blocks are pieces of fruit. Can you make a marvelous salad?
Imagine a delicious salad. Write about how it looks and tastes.
Choose colors for making a fruit salad. What colors did you choose?
What fruit in the story is your favorite? Can you write letters for some of the sounds that you hear?
Can you make Nita’s town?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Little Nita’s Big Idea by Anna W. Bardaus, illustrated by Carolina Farias. Copyright © 2017 by Scholastic Inc. Published by Scholastic Inc.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Produce at least 20 distinct letter-sound correspondences in the language of instruction.
Recognize rhyming words.
Demonstrate empathy and caring for others.
Make plans and take steps toward a goal.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions
Increase listening vocabulary and begin to develop vocabulary of object names and common phrases.
Identify good habits of nutrition and exercise.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Demonstrate empathy and caring for others.
Make plans and take steps toward a goal.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Show increasing control of tasks that require eye-hand coordination.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Segment a syllable from a word.
Discuss and contribute ideas for drafts composed in whole-/small-group writing activities.
Demonstrate empathy and caring for others.
Make plans and take steps toward a goal.
Use regular and irregular plurals, regular past tense, personal and possessive pronouns, and subject-verb agreement.
Identify good habits of nutrition and exercise.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Independently write to communicate ideas for a variety of purposes
Use letters to make words or parts of words.
Demonstrate empathy and caring for others.
Increase listening vocabulary and begin to develop vocabulary of object names and common phrases.
Child creates or recreates stories, moods, or experiences through dramatic representations.
Retell or reenact a story after it is read aloud.
Segment a syllable from a word.
Independently write to communicate ideas for a variety of purposes.
Use letters to make words or parts of words.
Make plans and take steps toward a goal.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Create or recreate stories, moods, or experiences through dramatic representations.
